name: 4-bromo-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzenesulfonamide
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. A bromine atom, being a large, electron-withdrawing group, typically raises the melting point significantly due to increased molecular weight and stronger intermolecular interactions (+60 °C). The trifluoromethyl group is highly electronegative and also increases the melting point due to the polar nature of the C–F bonds and the additional fluoro substituents' influence on the solid-state lattice (+40 °C). Lastly, the sulfonamide group adds substantial polar character and ability to form hydrogen bonds, leading to a strong increase in the melting point (+80 °C). The combined effect of these groups on benzene is expected to give a substantial cumulative increase in the melting point.
